These are the wrenching questions families across our district face if President Trump succeeds in destroying the Affordable Care Act. I know I will be fighting for Keith‚Äôs family and all the families I met with today across our district.

What happens if the law goes away? Will the insurance company raise gouge Keith because of his son‚Äôs pre-existing condition? Will he be able to stay on his dad‚Äôs insurance at all? If the ACA is repealed, Keith wonders: What happens to my son‚Äôs health care the next day?

Kyle has muscular dystrophy. It‚Äôs a tough disease -- and expensive to treat. Because the law allows young people to stay on their parents‚Äô plans, Kyle has been able to stay on his dad‚Äôs health insurance even as he headed off to college.

My last stop was an old friend: Keith in Howell. When the law allowing young adults to stay on their parents‚Äô insurance to age 26 passed, more than 2 million uninsured young people got coverage. Keith‚Äôs son is one. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EkAT3ZEX0AI4gGS.jpg

She told me what it was like to see young people who got coverage through their parents' insurance and self-employed workers who used their new coverage to establish a relationship with a health care provider for the first time.

Julie Thomas-Beckett is a nurse practitioner in the Lansing area who remembers what it was like before protections for pre-existing conditions and other provisions of the ACA became law. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Ej_-sHAXYAIuQYK.jpg

But those rules are threatened by the lawsuit now in front of the Supreme Court. If that lawsuit succeeds, costs for these simple preventive health measures are likely to go up, and the health of Robert‚Äôs patients to go down.

Those rules make it more likely his patients get things like annual checkups, screenings for things like breast cancer, even flu shots. It‚Äôs just one example of rules in place that lower costs and help us all stay healthy.

Robert Mavrogordato is a medical-surgical nurse in Lansing. At his practice, patients get treated regardless of insurance status -- but he sees first-hand the importance of current protection that make preventive care free of out-of-pocket costs. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Ej_b5QeWkAguW2S.jpg

I know how hard cancer is on families -- and how much harder it will be for families like Mark‚Äôs if they lose protections for pre-existing conditions. Yet doing away with those protections is just what the Trump administration is arguing for in court.

When Mark changed jobs a few years later, because of the protections currently in law, he was able to get coverage for the family on the health care exchange. And Susan‚Äôs pre-existing condition wasn‚Äôt a roadblock to getting covered.

Mark Collatz of East Lansing is a good example of how events from years ago will take on new significance if the Supreme Court tosses out protections for pre-existing conditions. Mark‚Äôs wife, Susan Loomis, survived brain cancer several years ago. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Ej_SSS8XYAA0kJV.jpg

Every community in our district has neighbors like Kara and Elizabeth. The ACA‚Äôs protections are a safety net for their families, but if the Trump administration‚Äôs lawsuit succeeds, that safety net would disappear.

Elizabeth‚Äôs coverage comes from her husband‚Äôs employer. Without the ACA, she knows that her husband‚Äôs insurance company could charge more for her care, and that if they ever lost his insurance, they‚Äôd struggle to find affordable coverage.

Under the ACA, Kara can keep her kids on her coverage until age 26 -- a protection that goes away if the Supreme Court invalidates the ACA. She‚Äôs not sure how she‚Äôll get coverage for their serious conditions without the ACA.

Next I stopped to talk to neighbors Kara Sprague and Elizabeth Kowal. Both Kara‚Äôs children have pre-existing conditions that would leave them exposed without ACA protections. Elizabeth herself has a pre-existing condition: diabetes. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Ej-pPixWoAEOkVG.jpg

First stop: Linda and Craig Brown of Clarkston. Their two sons have serious, chronic health conditions and even with Craig's coverage, they pay $40,000 a year for insurance. Her husband is holding off on retiring to keep that insurance. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Ej-eQ76XcAIScm4.jpg

We‚Äôre on the road for our tour across the 8th District, listening to constituents talk about what the Affordable Care Act means to them -- and what it would mean to lose the ACA. http://pbs.twimg.com/ext_tw_video_thumb/1314929160024924161/pu/img/ld0QdNZnDx0wUtjY.jpg https://video.twimg.com/ext_tw_video/1314929160024924161/pu/vid/468x270/DfJYjrJjU6pTWeW7.mp4?tag=10
